revisions.rev:
{{BLP sources|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Bernard Cribbins | image = | caption = Wilfred Mott talking to the [[Tenth Doctor|Doctor]] and [[Astrid Peth|Astrid]] in "[[Voyage of the Damned (Doctor Who)|Voyage of the Damned]]" | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1928|12|29|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Oldham]], [[Lancashire]], [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | other_names = | occupation = [[character actor]], musical [[comedian]] | spouse = Gillian Cribbins (1955-present) | children = | parents = | website = | awards = }} '''Bernard Cribbins''', [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (born 29 December 1928) is an [[England|English]] [[character actor]], [[voice-over]] artist and musical [[comedian]] with a career spanning over half a century who came to prominence in films in the 1960s, has been in work consistently since his professional debut in the mid 1950s, and as of 2010 is still an active performer. He is particularly known to British audiences as the story-telling voice in ''[[The Wombles]]'', a children's programme which ran for 40 episodes between 1973 and 1975. He also recorded several hit [[novelty record]]s in the early 1960s and was a regular and prolific performer on ''[[Jackanory]]'' on BBC TV between 1966 and 1991. Cribbins' most recent prominent role has been as [[Wilfred Mott]], [[Companion (Doctor Who)|companion]] of the [[Tenth Doctor]] in ''[[Doctor Who]]''. ==Early life== Born in [[Derker]], [[Oldham]], [[Lancashire]], Cribbins served an [[apprentice]]ship at the Oldham [[Repertory]] Theatre, taking a break during his years of study to undertake [[National Service]] with the [[Parachute Regiment (United Kingdom)|Parachute Regiment]] in his late teens.{{cite web|url=http://www.gavinbarkerassociates.co.uk/actors/bernard-cribbins.htm|title=Bernard Cribbins|publisher=Gavin Barker Associates|accessdate=2008-04-05}} ==Early stage and record career== Cribbins made his first [[West End theatre]] appearance in 1956 at the [[Arts Theatre]] playing the two Dromios in ''[[A Comedy of Errors]]'' and co-starred in the first West End productions of ''[[Not Now Darling]]'', ''[[There Goes the Bride (play)|There Goes the Bride]]'' and ''[[Run for Your Wife (play)|Run for Your Wife]]''. He also starred in the revue ''[[An' Another Thing]]'', and recorded a single of a song from the show entitled "Folksong". In 1962 he recorded two highly popular and well-remembered comic songs, "Right Said Fred" (in which a group of workmen struggle to relocate what would seem to be a piano) and "Hole in the Ground" (in which an embittered workman murders a bowler-hatted harasser). ==Films== Cribbins appeared in films from the early 1950s, mainly in comedies. His credits include ''[[Two Way Stretch]]'' (1960) and ''[[The Wrong Arm of the Law]]'' (1963) with [[Peter Sellers]], ''[[Crooks in Cloisters]]'' (1964) and three [[Carry On films|''Carry On'' films]] - ''[[Carry On Jack]]'' (1963), ''[[Carry On Spying]]'' (1964) and ''[[Carry On Columbus]]'' (1992). Other appearances include the second ''[[Doctor Who]]'' film ''[[Daleks - Invasion Earth 2150 AD]]'' (1966), Mr Albert Perks, the station porter, in ''[[The Railway Children (film)|The Railway Children]]'' (1970) and Felix Forsythe in [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s disturbing thriller ''[[Frenzy]]'' (1972). Later films include ''[[Dangerous Davies|Dangerous Davies - The Last Detective]]'' (1981) and ''[[Blackball (film)|Blackball]]'' (2003). ==Narration and voice work== He was the narrator of the British animated children's television series ''[[The Wombles]]'' from 1973 to 1975 and also narrated a celebrated [[BBC]] radio adaptation of ''[[The Wind in the Willows]]''. He was the celebrity storyteller in more episodes of ''[[Jackanory]]'' than any other personality, with a total of 114 appearances between 1966 and 1991. He provided the voice of the Tufty character in [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents|RoSPA]] road safety films in the 1960s. He also provided the voice of [[Buzby]], a talking cartoon bird that served as the mascot for the then [[General Post Office (United Kingdom)|Post Office]],which later became [[British Telecommunications]] when the two wings of the Post Office were demerged. He also appeared reduced to [[OO gauge]] in adverts for [[Hornby Railways|Hornby]] model trains.[http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/491092 screenonline: Cribbins, Bernard (1928-) Biography] ==Television== Other television appearances have included ''[[The Avengers (TV series)|The Avengers]]'' (1968), ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'' (1975), as the spoon salesman Mr. Hutchinson (mistaken by [[Basil Fawlty]] for a [[The Hotel Inspectors|hotel inspector]]), ''[[Worzel Gummidge]]'' (1980), ''[[Shillingbury Tales]]'' (1980) and its spin-off ''[[Cuffy (TV series)|Cuffy]]'' (1983). Later television appearances have included ''[[Dalziel and Pascoe]]'' (1999), ''[[Last of the Summer Wine]]'' (2003), the role of Wally Bannister in ''[[Coronation Street]]'' (2003) and ''[[Down to Earth (TV series)|Down to Earth]]'' (2005). ==Later stage career== Later theatre credits include playing Nathan Detroit in ''[[Guys and Dolls]]'' at the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]], Moonface Martin in ''[[Anything Goes]]'' with [[Elaine Paige]] at the [[Prince Edward Theatre]], Dolittle in ''[[My Fair Lady]]'' at the [[Houston, Texas|Houston]] Opera House, USA, and Watty Watkins in [[Gershwin]]'s ''[[Lady, Be Good (musical)|Lady, Be Good]]'' at the [[Regent's Park Open Air Theatre]] and on tour. He has also appeared in numerous [[pantomimes]].[http://www.gavinbarkerassociates.co.uk/actors/bernard-cribbins.htm Gavin Barker Associates Ltd: Bernard Cribbins Biography] ==Recent career== Cribbins returned to the world of Doctor Who in 2006 when a photograph of him at a wedding was used in the BBC's tie-in website {{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Torchwood House | work = | publisher = BBC | date = | url = http://www.visittorchwood.co.uk/weddings-quotes.htm VisitTorchwood.co.UK | format = | doi = | accessdate = 11 July 2011}} for "[[Tooth and Claw (Doctor Who)|Tooth and Claw]]". In January 2007, he [[guest star]]red as glam rock promoter Arnold Korns in the [[List of Doctor Who serials#Radio broadcasts|''Doctor Who'' radio play]] ''[[Horror of Glam Rock]]'' for [[BBC Radio 7]]. In December he appeared as [[Wilfred Mott]] in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' Christmas television special, "[[Voyage of the Damned (Doctor Who)|Voyage of the Damned]]"; he then reappeared as the same character throughout the [[Doctor Who (series 4)|2008 series]], as the [[grandfather]] of [[Companion (Doctor Who)|companion]] [[Donna Noble]]{{Cite news | last = | first = | author-link = | title = Into the Future! | newspaper = [[Doctor Who Magazine]] | pages = 4 | date = 19 September 2007 | url = | postscript = {{inconsistent citations}} }} He attained '[[Companion (Doctor Who)|companion]]' status himself in "[[The End of Time]]", the two-part Christmas 2009 special that saw the end of [[David Tennant]] in the role of the Doctor. This role makes him unique as he is the only actor to have faced the [[daleks]] in both television and cinema versions. ==Honours== Cribbins was appointed [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[2011 Birthday Honours]] for services to drama.{{London Gazette |issue=59808 |date=11 June 2011 |startpage=9 |supp=yes }}{{Cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13728375 |title=Bruce Forsyth knighthood heads Queen's Birthday Honours |author=[[BBC News]] |date=2011-06-11 |postscript={{inconsistent citations}}}} A large number of people complained about this, stating he should have received the higher honour of a [[Knight Bachelor|Knighthood]]. There are also a large amount of campaigns on social networking website, [[Facebook]], supporting the complaints.http://www.facebook.com/Bernard.Cribbins.for.Knighthood.Campaign ==Reception== Robert Ross praised him as Midshipman Albert Poop-Decker in ''[[Carry On Jack]],'' describing his bemused cheerfulness and comic ineptitude as a stunning debut performance.{{Cite web |url=http://books.google.com/?id=DoidQB3FcdgC&pg=PA40 |title=The Carry on Companion |author=Robert Ross |isbn=978-0-7134-8771-8 |date=2002-10-08 |postscript={{inconsistent citations}}}} ==Television== {| class="wikitable" |- !
